heading: the brightest and the fewer
subheading: fewer students are going after engineering, math, physics, and computer-science degrees. a new report by the american electronics association says high-tech degrees dropped 5 percent between 1990 and 1996, and preliminary numbers show the trend continued through 1998. the lack of trained workers is a common complaint in the technology industry. forty-five percent of the high-tech degrees went to foreign nationals, the study showed. last year, lobbyists successfully pressed congress to allow technology companies to hire more foreign workers with high-tech skills.
author: wired staff
